resources.string: Meditate so that mind cannot complicate life!
Zen Meditation (Zazen): - Means “seated Zen” or “seated meditation” HOW TO DO IT It is generally practiced seated on the floor over a mat and cushion, with crossed
means “insight” or “clear seeing” HOW TO DO IT one is to sit on a cushion on the floor, cross-legged, with your spine erect; alternatively, a chair may be used, but the back should not be supported.

Mindfulness of breathing, practice of intentionally focusing on the present moment HOW TO DO IT Pay close attention to the movement of your breath. When you breath in, be aware that you are breathing in, and how it feels. When you breath out, be aware you are breathing out.

(Metta Meditation): - boosting one’s ability to empathize with others; development of positive emotions through compassion, including a more loving attitude towards oneself HOW TO DO IT Sit down in a meditation position, with closed eyes. Develop feeling of kindness and benevolence. Process it by thinking of first oneself then a good friend then a neutral friend then a difficult person and then gradually the entire universe

A mantra (OM) is repeated for the purpose of focusing your mind. HOW TO DO IT it is usually practiced sitting with spine erect, and eyes closed. The practitioner then repeats the mantra in his mind, silently, over and over again during the whole session. the mantra is actually whispered very lightly and softly, as an aid to concentration.

Transcendental Meditation is a specific form of Mantra Meditation introduced by Maharishi Mahesh Yogi. It is a widely practiced form of meditation, many sponsored by the organization, demonstrating the benefits of the practice. HOW TO DO IT TM involves the use of a mantra and is practiced for 15–20 minutes twice per day while sitting with one’s eyes closed.

its highest goal spiritual purification and Self-Knowledge. Various Yoga Meditations are: -  Third Eye Meditation — focusing the attention on the “spot between the eyebrows”.  Chakra Meditation — the practitioner focuses on one of the seven chakras of the body (“centers of energy”).  Gazing Meditation (Trataka) — fixing the gaze on an external object, typically a candle, image or a symbol  Kundalini Meditation — this is a very complex system of practice. The goal is the awakening of the “kundalini energy”.  Kriya Yoga — is a set of energizations, breathing, and meditation exercises taught by Paramahamsa Yogananda.  Sound Meditation (Nada Yoga) — focusing on sound. Starts with meditation on “external sounds”, such as calming ambient music, whereby the student focuses all his attention on just hearing, as a help to quieten and collect the mind.  Pranayama — breathing regulation. It is not exactly meditation, but an excellent practice to calm the mind and prepare it for meditation.

It means to “investigate” our true nature, to find the answer to the “Who am I?” HOW TO DO practice is very simple, but also very subtle. It is there, in some form or another, behind all your thoughts, emotions, memories, and perceptions. There is no special position to practice, although the general suggestions about posture and environment are helpful for beginners.

It is an easier way to start, and you will find guided meditations based on several of the above traditions. HOW TO DO IT Guided meditation usually comes in the form of audio (file, podcast, CD), and sometimes audio and video.
